column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XIV
#Text=For two days at Semmering it rained .
#Text=The Raxalpe and the Schneeberg sulked behind walls of mist .
#Text=From the little balcony of the Pension Waldheim one looked out over a sea of cloud , pierced here and there by islands that were crags or by the tops of sunken masts that were evergreen trees .
#Text=The roads were masses of slippery mud , up which the horses steamed and sweated .
#Text=The gray cloud fog hung over everything ; the barking of a dog loomed out of it near at hand where no dog was to be seen .
#Text=Children cried and wild birds squawked ; one saw them not .
#Text=During the second night a landslide occurred on the side of the mountain with a rumble like the noise of fifty trains .
#Text=In the morning , the rain clouds lifting for a moment , Marie saw the narrow yellow line of the slip .
#Text=Everything was saturated with moisture .
#Text=It did no good to close the heavy wooden shutters at night : in the morning the air of the room was sticky and clothing was moist to the touch .
#Text=Stewart , confined to the house , grew irritable .
#Text=Marie watched him anxiously .
#Text=She knew quite well by what slender tenure she held her man .
#Text=They had nothing in common , neither speech nor thought .
#Text=And the little Marie 's love for Stewart , grown to be a part of her , was largely maternal .
#Text=She held him by mothering him , by keeping him comfortable , not by a great reciprocal passion that might in time have brought him to her in chains .
#Text=And now he was uncomfortable .
#Text=He chafed against the confinement ; he resented the food , the weather .
#Text=Even Marie 's content at her unusual leisure irked him .
#Text=He accused her of purring like a cat by the fire , and stamped out more than once , only to be driven in by the curious thunderstorms of early Alpine winter .
#Text=On the night of the second day the weather changed .
#Text=Marie , awakening early , stepped out on to the balcony and closed the door carefully behind her .
#Text=A new world lay beneath her , a marvel of glittering branches , of white plain far below ; the snowy mane of the Raxalpe was become a garment .
#Text=And from behind the villa came the cheerful sound of sleigh-bells , of horses ' feet on crisp snow , of runners sliding easily along frozen roads .
#Text=Even the barking of the dog in the next yard had ceased rumbling and become sharp staccato .
#Text=The balcony extended round the corner of the house .
#Text=Marie , eagerly discovering her new world , peered about , and seeing no one near ventured so far .
#Text=The road was in view , and a small girl on ski was struggling to prevent a collision between two plump feet .
#Text=Even as Marie saw her the inevitable happened and she went headlong into a drift .
#Text=A governess who had been kneeling before a shrine by the road hastily crossed herself and ran to the rescue .
#Text=It was a marvelous morning , a day of days .
#Text=The governess and the child went on out of vision .
#Text=Marie stood still , looking at the shrine .
#Text=A drift had piled about its foot , where the governess had placed a bunch of Alpine flowers .
#Text=Down on her knees on the balcony went the little Marie , regardless of the snow , and prayed to the shrine of the Virgin below -- for what ? For forgiveness ?
#Text=For a better life ?
#Text=Not at all .
#Text=She prayed that the heels of the American girl would keep her in out of the snow .
#Text=The prayer of the wicked availeth nothing ; even the godly at times must suffer disappointment .
#Text=And when one prays of heels , who can know of the yearning back of the praying ?
#Text=Marie , rising and dusting her chilled knees , saw the party of Americans on the road , clad in stout boots and swinging along gayly .
#Text=Marie shrugged her shoulders resignedly .
#Text=She should have gone to the shrine itself ; a balcony was not a holy place .
#Text=But one thing she determined -- the Americans went toward the Sonnwendstein .
#Text=She would advise against the Sonnwendstein for that day .
#Text=Marie 's day of days had begun wrong after all .
#Text=For Stewart rose with the Sonnwendstein in his mind , and no suggestion of Marie 's that in another day a path would be broken had any effect on him .
#Text=He was eager to be off , committed the extravagance of ordering an egg apiece for breakfast , and finally proclaimed that if Marie feared the climb he would go alone .
#Text=Marie made many delays : she dressed slowly , and must run back to see if the balcony door was securely closed .
#Text=At a little shop where they stopped to buy mountain sticks she must purchase postcards and send them at once .
#Text=Stewart was fairly patient : air and exercise were having their effect .
#Text=It was eleven o'clock when , having crossed the valley , they commenced to mount the slope of the Sonnwendstein .
#Text=The climb was easy ; the road wound back and forward on itself so that one ascended with hardly an effort .
#Text=Stewart gave Marie a hand here and there , and even paused to let her sit on a boulder and rest .
#Text=The snow was not heavy ; he showed her the footprints of a party that had gone ahead , and to amuse her tried to count the number of people .
#Text=When he found it was five he grew thoughtful .
#Text=There were five in Anita 's party .
#Text=Thanks to Marie 's delays they met the Americans coming down .
#Text=The meeting was a short one : the party went on down , gayly talking .
#Text=Marie and Stewart climbed silently .
#Text=Marie 's day was spoiled ; Stewart had promised to dine at the hotel .
